results.headline: When You Plan to Die Alone, Prepare for Lots of Company

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Henry Poole Is Here

results.summary_short: With characters named Esperanza, Dawn and Patience, “Henry Poole Is Here” traffics in the kind of inspirational kitsch that only a true believer could swallow.

results.headline: Space in 3-D

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fly Me to the Moon

results.summary_short: “Fly Me to the Moon” bills itself as the first animated feature created expressly for 3-D. Too bad it wasn’t created expressly for, you know, pleasure or art.

results.headline: An Animated Force

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Star Wars: The Clone Wars

results.summary_short: “Star Wars: The Clone Wars” comes as something of a surprise: it isn’t the most painful movie of the year!

results.headline: Painting His Fears
results.display_title: One Bad Cat: The Reverend Albert Wagner Story

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One Bad Cat: The Reverend Albert Wagner Story

results.summary_short: Directed by Thomas G. Miller, “One Bad Cat” brings fresh light to the artist Albert Wagner.

results.headline: Shepherds, Nymphs, Despair and Love
results.display_title: The Romance of Astrea and Celadon

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Romance of Astrea and Celadon

results.summary_short: The nymphs and druids who frolic through “The Romance of Astrea and Celadon” occupy mythological space between Shakespeare and Greek mythology.

results.headline: War May Be Hell, but Hollywood Is Even Worse

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tropic Thunder

results.summary_short: “Tropic Thunder” is a flashy, nasty, on-and-off funny and assaultive sendup of the film industry.

results.headline: Extracurricular Lessons for Student and Teacher

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Elegy

results.summary_short: “Elegy” is such a serious, oftentimes grave exploration of desire and the ways of aging that it’s a miracle the two central characters have as much sex as they do.

results.headline: On the Run

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Spirit of the Marathon

results.summary_short: A symphony of snapping sinews and pumping thighs, “Spirit of the Marathon” makes you feel like a slug.

results.headline: In Search of Posthumous Adulation

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of What We Do is Secret

results.summary_short: “What We Do Is Secret” reveals its hero, Darby Crash, as a disaffected egotist and a magnet for needy weirdoes.

results.headline: Bearing Witness to a Historical Disgrace

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Passing Poston

results.summary_short: “Passing Poston” recollects one of the most shameful episodes in United States history: the forced internment of American citizens of Japanese descent during World War II.

results.headline: It’s Not About the Bike? Try Telling These Lifers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hell Ride

results.summary_short: “Hell Ride,” a silly slice of genre gone bad, takes place in an American desert populated by middle-aged bikers and the nubile, often topless young women who love them.

results.headline: A Simple Country Soul Pushed Past His Limits

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Red

results.summary_short: “Red” imagines a world in which good and evil are clear-cut, and absolute justice is worth pursuing despite heavy collateral damage.

results.headline: An Arrival for the Dearly Departed

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Last Stop for Paul

results.summary_short: “Last Stop for Paul” follows two goofy dudes, Charlie (Neil Mandt) and Cliff (Marc Carter), as they gallivant around the globe in search of adventure.

results.headline: Keeping It Real, Totally, Y’Know, Back in the Day

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beautiful Losers

results.summary_short: “Beautiful Losers” bids to immortalize the ethos and achievement of a group of artists affiliated with the Alleged Gallery in Manhattan.

results.headline: Stigmatized by Society

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Forgotten Woman

results.summary_short: “The Forgotten Woman,” about the marginalization of widows in India, has visual beauty, graceful compassion and understated anger.

results.headline: Godmother of Punk, Celebrator of Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Patti Smith: Dream of Life

results.summary_short: You may not learn everything you want to know in “Patti Smith: Dream of Life,” but you learn just about everything you need.

results.headline: Stoners Who Put the Bud in Buddies

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pineapple Express

results.summary_short: “Pineapple Express” is a stoner comedy that partakes of a gentle indie vibe before hitting the hard stuff.

results.headline: Four Jills in Jeans (One Pair) Go to College, Find Romance (or Not), Stay Connected
results.display_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2

results.summary_short: This is the movie equivalent of being patted on the shoulder by an encouraging high school guidance counselor and assured that you are doing just fine.

results.headline: Plaid Suits, Prize Grapes and the Rise of Napa

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bottle Shock

results.summary_short: “Bottle Shock” reconstructs a watershed moment in the wine world’s acceptance of the Golden State.

results.headline: Only a Few More Smuggling Days Left Before Christmas? It’s Not a Wonderful Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Frozen River

results.summary_short: Courtney Hunt’s somber film “Frozen River” ventures deep into the trenches where hard-working Americans struggle to put food on the table.
